text: @Etsy would be super interested to hear about packages for working with field data! I’ve heard of lots of python, less julia

elements.text: @Etsy would be super interested to hear about packages for working with field data! I’ve heard of lots of python, less julia

text: eg <https://github.com/modscripps>

elements.text: eg

text: Same, seems more modeling oriented, but I think that might be because it’s a young language and so fewer field scientists have heard of it let alone promote it. I have even had pushback in the past for using python instead of matlab.

elements.text: Same, seems more modeling oriented, but I think that might be because it’s a young language and so fewer field scientists have heard of it let alone promote it. I have even had pushback in the past for using python instead of matlab.

text: The genetics people are a little more lenient, they started off with bioperl and then went to biopython. Wonder will biojulia become a thing ever Hahaha

elements.text: The genetics people are a little more lenient, they started off with bioperl and then went to biopython. Wonder will biojulia become a thing ever Hahaha

text: yeah

elements.text: yeah

text: I think there’s a fair amount of python at least in physical observation oceanography nowadays, starting with lots of work at U Hawaii, Eric Firing, but now seemingly fairly wide spread

elements.text: I think there’s a fair amount of python at least in physical observation oceanography nowadays, starting with lots of work at U Hawaii, Eric Firing, but now seemingly fairly wide spread

text: I think scripts / tools for processing instrument data, etc tend to be complicated custom scripting jobs and the MO is to pass around matlab scripts amongst friends

elements.text: I think scripts / tools for processing instrument data, etc tend to be complicated custom scripting jobs and the MO is to pass around matlab scripts amongst friends

text: It is. I worked with folks from hawaii in the past on fieldwork (among others). Personally I think python, at least in my subfield, was promoted heavily by AWI

elements.text: It is. I worked with folks from hawaii in the past on fieldwork (among others). Personally I think python, at least in my subfield, was promoted heavily by AWI

text: There are some julia tools that might be useful for obs here: <https://github.com/gher-ulg>

elements.text: There are some julia tools that might be useful for obs here:

text: but 100% of my classes were matlab oriented. Which was a shame

elements.text: but 100% of my classes were matlab oriented. Which was a shame

text: Alexander Barth maintains `NCDatasets.jl` which is a fairly impt julia package

NCDatasets.jl
which is a fairly impt julia package

text: back during my BSc anyway.

elements.text: back during my BSc anyway.

text: I did landbased stuff (glaciers) during my Masters and that was mostly Python (because of GIS)

elements.text: I did landbased stuff (glaciers) during my Masters and that was mostly Python (because of GIS)

text: I think there’s probably a fair number of people that might be receptive to julia in observational oceanography, just needs a little leadership to get going

elements.text: I think there’s probably a fair number of people that might be receptive to julia in observational oceanography, just needs a little leadership to get going

text: julia has some applications in instrument development too, so there’s hardware people / engineers interested in it, in addition to scientists

elements.text: julia has some applications in instrument development too, so there’s hardware people / engineers interested in it, in addition to scientists

text: Yup, it’’s all the old fogeys (And I mean that in the nicest possible way) who want to not use a new language, since half of them started in Fortran or C and don’t want to now learn yet another language. They have so little time already between grant applications and everything else

elements.text: Yup, it’’s all the old fogeys (And I mean that in the nicest possible way) who want to not use a new language, since half of them started in Fortran or C and don’t want to now learn yet another language. They have so little time already between grant applications and everything else

text: we also have a package that might have some use (but is primarily for modeling): <https://github.com/CliMA/SeawaterPolynomials.jl>

elements.text: we also have a package that might have some use (but is primarily for modeling):

text: Thanks so much for all of this :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Thanks so much for all of this

text: I was working on porting gibbs seawater, but someone already beat me to it (someone with far more experience than me haha)

elements.text: I was working on porting gibbs seawater, but someone already beat me to it (someone with far more experience than me haha)

text: i thikn you’re right that most people don’t have time for software development --- but i think if you handed them shiny software for doing the things they were interested in (eg analyzing CTD data, gridding, etc) that worked really well and maybe provided some capabilities that other software didnt have, people might be interested

elements.text: i thikn you’re right that most people don’t have time for software development --- but i think if you handed them shiny software for doing the things they were interested in (eg analyzing CTD data, gridding, etc) that worked really well and maybe provided some capabilities that other software didnt have, people might be interested

text: there are also some compute-intensive stuff, like analyzing multibeam data, that could be interesting to implement in julia

elements.text: there are also some compute-intensive stuff, like analyzing multibeam data, that could be interesting to implement in julia

text: If I ever start teaching in the next couple of years, then I can assign some things. That should improve uptake. But as of yet I am not teaching.

elements.text: If I ever start teaching in the next couple of years, then I can assign some things. That should improve uptake. But as of yet I am not teaching.

text: I love multibeam, but I spent far too much time manually editing erroneous pings (e.g. schools of fish)
